entry.title: FineBI E-commerce Platform Consumer Data Visualisation
entry.content:
1. FineBI E-commerce Platform Consumer Data Visualisation

1.1. Project Background

Comprehending and interpreting data is crucial in the world of business. With the help of Business Intelligence (BI) tools, we aim to analyse data from a business context, providing in-depth insights and bringing forth practical commercial value. We employed techniques such as the RFM Model, Shopping Basket Analysis, and Pareto (ABC) principles to create visualisations for the management personnel in the sales and operations departments, with the goal of promoting “data-empowered decision-making”.

Project Link: FineBI E-commerce Platform Consumer Data Visualisation
Project Timeline: 04/16/2022 - 04/29/2022
Role: E-commerce Data Analyst
Tools Used: Python (Pandas, Numpy, FineBI, etc.)
Source Data: The primary data source of our project is the business performance data, which includes sales and operational metrics. This data set contains valuable information that aids in understanding the overall business performance.
Responsibilities: Project Management / Article Production / Application of RFM Model / Part of FineBI Charts Design

1.2. Project Process

  1. Employed Pandas for data processing, handling null values, missing values, duplicated values and insignificant columns
  2. Deployed Dashboard for visualisation of Model(RFM/Pareto(ABC)/Basket Analysis and etc.) results
  3. presented conclusions and suggestions based on the analysis results

1.3. Project Value

  1. Conducted a multi-dimensional breakdown of the overall data to identify leading products and related combination product categories to further increase sales revenue
  2. Utilised time-series and RFM model for precision operations on users, laying the groundwork for subsequent experiments (e.g., labelling price-sensitive users)

2. Detailed Report

2.1. Analysis Objectives

Our data analysis objectives mainly include the following aspects:

  1. Seasonal and geographical trends in sales.
  2. User activity patterns and customer retention rates.
  3. Gaining insights to drive sales strategies and improve operational efficiency.

2.2. Analysis Results and Suggestions

Our data analysis reveals the following key findings, based on which we propose some marketing strategy suggestions:

  1. Sales were higher in the third quarter, and some regions like Shanghai, Beijing, and Guangdong showed higher sales numbers.
  2. There was a trend of increased user activity between July and August, and the overall customer retention rate was on an upward trajectory.
  3. Our key retained customers significantly contributed to consumption.

2.3. Conclusion

Our journey of exploring BI tools, understanding data analysis models, building an efficient dashboard, and drawing commercial insights has been enlightening.

entry.title: Exploring JD Consumer Behaviour: User Tagging and Clipping
entry.content:
1. JD Consumer Behaviour Report

1.1. Project Background

Understanding consumer purchasing behaviour and preferences is crucial in the e-commerce platform. In this project, we utilise Python to process and analyse historical order data and user behaviour data from JD, a leading e-commerce platform, in an attempt to identify opportunities for optimisation within the e-commerce platform through statistical analysis and to provide pertinent recommendations.

Project Link: Exploring JD Consumer Behaviour: User Tagging and Clipping
Project Timeline: 02/02/2022 - 09/02/2022
Role: E-commerce Data Analyst
Tools Used: Python (Pandas, Numpy, Pyecharts, etc.)
Source Data: The dataset for this project comprises two parts: one part is the actual purchase order data generated by users, and the other part is user preference data collected through daily operations.

1.2. Project Process

  1. Employed Pandas for data processing, handling null values, missing values, duplicated values and insignificant columns
  2. Deployed Pyecharts for visualisation of descriptive statistical results
  3. Established hypotheses by excavating product and user behaviour features via time series analysis
  4. Conducted hypothesis verification and presented conclusions

1.3. Project Value

  1. Focused on the user, we have delved into various dimensions including product combinations, active periods, and advertisement placements, thereby offering optimisation recommendations
  2. Provided a sales and operations perspective for business personnel and e-commerce merchants
  3. Proposed potential directions for further exploration, such as precision operations for users and product recommendations

2. Detailed Report

2.1. Analysis Objectives

Our data analysis objectives mainly include the following aspects:

  1. Determine the most popular product categories and subcategories among consumers.
  2. For specific subcategories, identify the most popular and best-selling brands.
  3. Analyse the overall order quantity and trends on different dates.
  4. Study seasonal purchasing behaviour, such as changes in clothing purchase quantities from winter to spring 1. (season change).
  5. For the mobile phone industry, analyse the sales changes of major brands on different dates.
  6. Identify the most purchased products and products that users are willing to repurchase.
  7. Identify the most browsed, most collected, and most frequently added to the shopping cart products by users.

2.2. Analysis Results and Suggestions

Our data analysis reveals the following key findings, based on which we propose some marketing strategy suggestions:

  1. Users have a high enthusiasm for electronic products and clothes, suggesting that the e-commerce platform could conduct joint promotions with related brands.
  2. Users have high purchasing power during the Spring Festival, but the order amount drops after the festival, suggesting post-festival marketing activities to stimulate consumption.
  3. Users prefer to browse and purchase on the e-commerce platform in the afternoon and evening, suggesting increased advertising efforts during these times.
  4. More than half of the users have not logged into the e-commerce platform, suggesting activities to attract returning customers.

2.3. Conclusion

Although the content of this analysis needs further improvement, it has already provided us with some important insights into consumer behaviour on JD.com. We will continue to improve our analysis methods to provide a deeper and more comprehensive understanding.

entry.title: Improving Community Retention: An Investigation into Retention Enhancement in a CSDN-like Content Community
entry.content:
1. JD Consumer Behaviour Report

1.1. Project Background

Understanding user behaviour on digital platforms is crucial for enhancing user experience and driving business growth. This project aims to provide an in-depth analysis of user behaviour on a digital platform, revealing patterns and preferences in user actions such as browsing, purchasing, sharing, and liking.

Project Link: How to Improve Community Retention: An Exploration of Retention Enhancement in a CSDN-like Content Community
Project Timeline: 12/02/2022 - 03/03/2022
Role: Data Operations Analyst / Project Management
Tools Used: Python (Pandas, Numpy, Pyecharts, Seaborn, etc.)
Source Data: The dataset for this project comprises two parts: one part is the actual purchase order data generated by users, and the other part is user preference data collected through daily operations.
Responsibilities: Project Management / Idea Design / Article Production / Data Processing and Analysis with Pandas / Visualisation with Pyecharts
Data Source: The dataset for this project comprises user behaviour data collected from the platform, including actions such as viewing, buying, sharing, liking, rewarding, and participating in activities.

1.2. Project Process

  1. Conducted data processing with Pandas, managing null values, missing values, duplicates, and data formatting
  2. Established a research outline for the visualisation of retention and activity rates across different dimensions
  3. Implemented user segmentation based on the Recency, Frequency, Monetary (RFM) model for precision operations
  4. Conducted comparative analysis of user behaviour (cohort analysis) and behaviour correlation analysis

1.3. Project Value

  1. Identified key differential behaviours (Aha-Moment) between low-retention and high-retention users
  2. Applied the RFM model for precision user operations and researched key indicators for improving retention rates
  3. Provided core recommendations for platform operations, such as new user onboarding

2. Detailed Report

2.1. Analysis Objectives

Our data analysis objectives mainly include the following aspects:

  1. Determine the frequency of different user actions on the platform and identify any trends or patterns.
  2. Identify any anomalies in the frequency of user actions and investigate potential causes.
  3. Analyse the correlation between different user actions.
  4. Identify key user actions that influence other user behaviours.

2.2. Analysis Results and Suggestions

Our data analysis reveals the following key insights:

  1. The frequency of user actions on the platform (such as browsing, buying, sharing, liking) shows certain trends. For example, the frequency of user browsing behaviour has the highest similarity with the PV/UV graph of the day/month. There is an anomaly in the frequency of user collection behaviour in mid-August, but no explanatory factors can be proposed at present. The frequency of user rewarding behaviour has a peak in November, which may be related to the actual appearance of popular articles/resources in November. User activity behaviour has certain peaks in July and December, but the specific effects need further observation.
  2. The analysis raises some questions and speculations, such as: Does the behaviour object ID (target_id) contain other objects besides article objects (e.g., user objects, activity objects, product objects, etc.)? If a user buys/likes/shares/collects/participates in an activity, does the user need to view this page first? If a user gives a reward, what does the behaviour object ID (target_id) point to? Is it another user or an article?
  3. The analysis provides answers to the above questions. For example, if a user buys/likes/shares/collects, the user needs to view this page first. If a user gives a reward, the user definitely does not reward another user, nor a shareable and purchasable object. It may be a column or resource file (reward to download). If a user shares (Share), the user just shares the content (the first major class object).
  4. The analysis also conducted a correlation analysis of various indicators, finding that whether it is high-quality users or overall users, they have a high degree of association in the following pairs of behaviours: view and buy, view and share, reward and share, reward and comp. Looking at the points where the difference in behaviour correlation between high-quality users and overall users is high, the correlation between vote and other behaviours has a large increase (except for buy). This may indicate that vote may be a key factor influencing other user behaviours.

2.3. Conclusion

Although the content of this analysis needs further improvement, it has already provided us with some important insights into user behaviour on the digital platform. We will continue to improve our analysis methods to provide a deeper and more comprehensive understanding.

entry.title: Visualisation of Operating Data of Wa Lai Da Ban Ke with Tableau
entry.content:
1. Visualisation of Operating Data of Wa Lai Da Ban Ke with Tableau

1.1. Project Background

The project’s objective is to aid the operational personnel and management team of Wa Lai Da Ban Ke brand in understanding the growth of their various stores and dynamically devising their decision-making policies. By leveraging Tableau, a powerful data visualisation tool, we aim to transform raw operational data into insightful dashboards.

Project Link: Visualisation of Operating Data of Wa Lai Da Ban Ke with Tableau
Project Timeline: 04/16/2022 - 04/20/2022
Role: E-commerce Data Analyst
Tools Used: Python (Pandas, Excel, Tableau, etc.)

1.2. Project Process

  1. Employed Pandas for data processing, handling null values, missing values, duplicated values and insignificant columns
  2. Deployed Tableau Dashboard for visualisation of Data results

2. Detailed Report

2.1. Analysis Objectives

Our data analysis objectives mainly include the following aspects:

  1. Understanding the sales and growth patterns across different Wa Lai Da Ban Ke stores.
  2. Identifying trends and correlations in sales data that can aid in decision-making.
  3. Providing visual representations of business data that can be easily understood and acted upon by the management team.

2.2. Analysis Results and Suggestions

Through the Tableau dashboard, we visualise the growth situation across various Wa Lai Da Ban Ke stores. This not only aids in tracking sales performance but also helps identify trends and patterns that can guide strategic business decisions.

2.3. Conclusion

The project underscores the significant role of data visualisation in understanding business operations and making informed decisions. The power of Tableau as a BI tool is harnessed in this project, allowing for a dynamic and comprehensive understanding of business growth across various stores. This project offers an insightful resource for business personnel and the management team to keep a pulse on operational performance and to steer future strategies.
